page.title: 13LEVER'S CASTLE
page.content: William Hesketh Lever,Viscount Leverhulme,provided much of interest in his country park.Permanent memorials to him were erected by his son in the form of two pylons pitched like giant gateposts at the foot of Lever Park Avenue,initially his carriage drive to the bungalow.One of Lever's own memorials was the castle he built at the edge of the geeat lake of Rivington reservoir. Ir comes in the tradition of Victorian follies for it is a mere copy of Liverpool Castle.As this had been severly damaged in the English Civil War, all that Lever could copy was a ruined shell with battered ramparts. Yet copy it he did and it does provide a sudden surprising sight on a hillock close to the Rivington reservoir.You approach it along one of his tree-lined avenues.
